brief_hospital_course: patient was admitted to the icu on  for new onset acute renal failure cr of 12 and ck of 93000 and with elevated transaminases as well rhabdomyolysis patient initially presented with highly elevated ck and  etiology of rhabdomyolosis considered as a sequelae of recent bike accident and concaine use the possibility of compartment syndrome was considered however physical exam was not cw this diagnosis also on differential was hiv given his risk factors and erlichiosis given that he is from the  but parasite smear at osh negative and pt does not recall tick bite pt was given aggressive fluid repletion initially with ns and then with  ns c 15 amps bicarb pts bicarb was followed to ensure that metabolic acidosis was not entirely corrected as metabolic acidosis is protective for hypocalcemic seizures both by raising seizure threshold and by decreasing the fraction of calcium bound to albumin pts electrolytes were trended pt was significantly hypocalcemic but without symptoms the calcium was not repleted as it was felt that pt would soon become significantly hypercalcemic  lysis of muscle cells ck and uric acid were also trended and they slowly trended down ivf were eventually discontinued secondary to pts poor urine output and increasing volume overload hiv and hepatits serologies were negative  upon transfer to the floor he continued improve with intermittent hd and fluid support  his ck trended down and he did well  acute renal failure initial differential consists of rhabdomyolysis dic ttphus severe babesiosis given   location renal was consulted and felt that this presentation was typical of atn  rhabdomyolysis  labs were negative as was parasite smear pt recieved aggressive fluid hydration as above pts renal function did not improve over initial several days in micu pt was thus started on hemodialysis on hd  he improved after 2 rounds of hd and continued to mobilize fluids  his creatinine plateaued in the mid with good urine output  he was able to void on his own without any issues acute hepatitis patient initially presented with transaminitis with initial differential including rhabdomyolosis alt and ast from muscle source rather than liver hepatitis bc given polysubstance abuse history severe babesiosis acetaminophen toxicity and alcoholic hepatitis unlikely as tox screen was negative hepatitis b and c serologies were consistent only with prior hepatitis b vaccination ruq us was unremarkable for liver process and parasite smear was negative for babesiosis x2 osh and here  as he improved his lfts returned to normal right upper extremity dvt pt found to have increased edema in right upper extremity and an ultrasound was done which did show dvt pt was started on heparin gtt lovenox not an option give   repeat rue us prior to discharge showed no clot given resolved clot and low chance of clot in his baseline medical condition healthy  yom prior to rhabdo and his new retroperitoneal bleed  heparin gtt was stopped before dischargeright flank painrp hematoma patient had right flank pain that was persistent after arrived on the floor  given his history of trauma and recent anticoagulation due to his ru dvt retroperitoneal bleed was considered ct of abdomen was done to eval for abnormalities and rp bleed was identified  serial hct was stable vss and hd stable  he was discharged with follow up instructions to his pcp polysubstance usepain patient admitted to actively using cocaine and alcohol sw consulted pt complained of severe diffuse muscle pain more than would be expected for rhabdomyolsis compartment syndrome was considered but pts extremities remained warm and well perfused with good pulses also pt could not localize his pain to any one extremity pt was felt to likely be withdrawing from opioids pt does report occasional heroin use and  other prescription medications pt was initially treated c fentanyl boluses and then transitioned to po morphine plus mscontin which were then slowly weaned pt treated with nephrocaps thiamine folate  he was asymptomatic throughout his stay on the floor and remained so at discharge  anemia hct 332 on admit with mcv 89 at osh hct 38 dic hemolysis ttp were considered however other hemolysis andor dic labs were negative pts hematocrits were trended and an active type and screen maintained  he remained stable at discharge  anion gap vomiting over 5 days hyponatremia may be due to hypovolemia and gi losses serial nas were monitored and stable and ivf resuscitation was continued  resolved on the floor prior to discharge  thrombocytopenia differential diagnosis included liver disease splenic sequestration drugrelated alcohol use babesiosis and hiv hiv and hepatitis serologies were negative platelet counts were trended and stable     hypoechogenic focus r kidney while findings could represent a prominent pyramid septated cyst is also a possibility recommend further evaluation with a renal protocol mri or ct on a brief_hospital_course: yo m with dm2 htn pvd and dementia admitted with generalized weakness found to have fevers due to a pneumoniathe patient presented with generalized weakness at home soon after admission he was found to have fevers and a cough initial evaluation did not reveal an acute process however repeat cxr after hydration did in fact reveal a probable retrocardiac opacity he will complete 7 days of levofloxacin therapy for a community acquired pneumonia the remainder of the workup did not reveal any other significant abnormalities he had no leukocytosis no significant metabolic abnormality except for chronic kidney disease and recently normal vitamin b12 folate tsh and rpr he had a negative ekg for acute ischemia and ua blood cultures are thus far without growth the patient was seen by the neurology consult service who communicated with his outpatient neurologist he was felt to have no change in his baseline mental status with mixed vascular and alzheimers dementia he also had no significant changes in his baseline neurologic exam head ct showed chronic unchanged ventricular enlargement potentially consistent with nph though his outpatient neurologist and the neurology consult service felt this was unlikely based upon exam and history and further workup can be considered as an outpatientrarely galantamine  which had recently been started on this patient  can cause fevers after discussion with his outpatient neurologist this medication was stopped it had originally been started because the patients  pharmacy stopped carrying aricept and offered galantamine as a therapeutic interchange outpatient consideration can be made to restart aricept for now he continues on namenda the patient was persistently disoriented and at times agitated in the hospital he has a history of similar behavior with reorienting he was generally able to follow requests though he frequently refused vital signs and labs he can receive zydis dissolving tab as necessary for agitationhe was seen by  who felt he required physical rehab he also requires placement in a dementia unit the patients wife agreed with this assessmentcode status is do not intubate however his wife states that he would want chest compressions electrical shocks and code medications he would not want prolonged or futile code treatment

pericarditis and the patient was treated empirically for pericarditis tte showed a trivial pericardial effusion and preserved global left ventricular systolic function with a mildly dilated aortic sinus as the patient was unable to receive nsaids due to known cad and questionable gi bleed on last admission he was started on colchicine and prednisone this combination improved his chest pain note for full details he tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the cvicu in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring after a few hours he suddenly started drainingincreasing amount of blood from the chest tubes especially the left pleural chest tube with a hematocrit and a chest x ray showing left pleural collection  he remained hemodynamically stable he was taken back to the operating room for reexploration after removing the clots a single left internal mammary artery pedicle bleeder was found which was actively bleeding and this was controlled with a ligaclip  after clearing all the clots from the left chest and washing out the chest tubes were repositioned and after 1 further inspection of all the surgical sites no other bleeding was found he was again transferred to the cvicu in stable condition for recovery and invasive monitoring he weaned from sedation awoke somewhat delirious but was extubated on pod 1 he was weaned from inotropic and vasopressor support he was treated for delirium in the icu with haldol and this slowly resolved pod2 he had a repeat echo due to a hematocrit drop and this showed no pericardial effusion or collection beta blocker was initiated and he was diuresed toward his preoperative weight he was transfused a unit of rbc for a hct 21 and this remained stable throughout the remainder of his hospital course pacing wires were removed he remained hemodynamically stable and was transferred to the telemetry floor for further recovery chest tubes remained in until pod4 due to copious serous drainage these were removed without complication he was evaluated by the physical therapy service for assistance with strength and mobility by the time of discharge on pod 6 he was ambulating with assistance the wound was healing and pain was controlled with oral analgesics he remained on his chronic antibiotics for a previous right knee infection he was discharged to   rehab in good condition with appropriate follow up instructions

brief_hospital_course: global assessmentmr  is a  single unemployed on ssdi hiv positive man with history of depression alcohol use disorder numerous psychiatric hospitalizations and  prior suicide attempts including od on tylenol in  who presented to  ed acutely intoxicated and on sober evaluation expressed worsening depression and suicidal ideation in the context of ongoing alcohol use absence of psychiatric treatment and severe social stressors initial examination revealed an unkempt dypshoric man with low mood and neurovegetative symptom consistent with depressionhis hopelessness fatigue and amotivation over the last several months have led to noncompliance with hiv medications and escalating alcohol use both of which have contributed to a significant deterioration in his physical and emotional health mr  decompensation is intimately related to severe social stressors including financial hardship risk of eviction and caring for a sick and abusive mother and the absence of any psychosocial support figures diagnostically patient most likely has a substance induced mood disorder superimposed on a primary mood disorder although a mood disorder secondary to another medical condition hiv is also a possibility legal safety  mr  was calm and controlled on the unit there were no safetybehavioral issues he was kept on standard q15 minute checks and unit restriction psychiatricdiagnosesdifferential  alcohol use disorder  substance induced mood disorder  history of major depressive disorder  ro mood disorder secondary to other medical conditionextensive time was spent discussing the mr  diagnosis and psychopharmacology issues he participated in treatment planningmr  was not on any psychiatric medications at time of admission he was started on citalopram to treat his depression braese including but not limited to sedation gi upset overactivation were discussed this medication was welltolerated and likely contributed to the improvement in patients dypshoria and neurovegetative symptomsearly interviews were notable for extended pauses before answering questions which raised concern for hiv associated dementia a moca examination was completed and he scored  with deficits in visuospatialexecutive function attention language and delayed recall mr  was subsequently referred for neuropsychological testing on rbans neuropsychiatric test mr  demonstrated subtle deficits in new learning immediate memory and delayed memory which could signify early prodromal signs of dementia in a patient who is generally of average to high intelligence the majority of his scores were within one standard deviation of the mean for his age list recognition was the only task greater than two sds below the mean mr  did very well with digit span a task patients with significant cognitive deficits typically struggle with overall the results were not consistent with a clear neurocognitive disorder but he should be monitored for ongoing cognitive collapse clinically his cognitive status improved over the course of the hospitalization suggesting that alcohol and depression may have been significant factorsmr  initially stated that he had no outpatient providers but later informed team that he had seen a social worker through  at the  this therapist   was contacted on  her discussions with mr  generally focused on his relationship with his mother and their evolving codependence he was unwilling to discuss his substance abuse with her and denied he had any problem in the past few months he had stopped seeing her or taking his medications and believed he was far from his baseline based on the description of his initial evaluation believing him to be acutely decompensated secondary to depression and substance usethroughout his hospitalization he began to become more forward thinking and future oriented for example he began working on necessary arrangements to care for his finances which he had neglected for several months furthermore he made arrangements to assure he would receive his proper hiv medications upon his transfer to  showing he had overcome the passive suicidality of medication noncompliance that was of initial concern upon admission substance use alcoholpatient arrived at the emergency room intoxicated he was monitored on ciwa during the first few days of hospitalization and completed detoxification without incidentpatient was educated on the way in which drugs and alcohol affect behavior mood interpersonal relationships and physical health  patient was encouraged to abstain from all alcohol and illicit drug use and participate in aana on a daily basis upon discharge from inpatient facilitiesin terms of treatment readiness patient was in precontemplation stage he described alcohol as his obsession and avoided talking about the consequences of his drinking or initiating treatment that would support his sobreity throughout his hospitalization he became more acknowledging of his alcohol use and agreed that further treatment at  specifically for his alcohol use would be beneficial  medicalpatients pcp  was contacted during the admission in order to discuss circumstances of patients hospitalization obtain relevant history and arrange appropriate follow upthe following medical problems were addressed during this hospitalization  transaminitis likely elevated in setting of alcohol use and nash lfts were initially uptrending to 300 but then began to slowly downtrend synthetic function inr remained within normal limits liver service was consulted and given the reassuring trend and normal ruq ultrasound did not feel that any further testing or intervention was required   aids restarted antivirals truvada atazanavir ritonavir cd4 count 702 on admission  hypertension hypertensive early in the hospitalization which was initially thought to be secondary to alcohol withdrawal however given its persistence lisinopril 5mg daily was started on  which resulted in normalization of pressures  arthritis restarted home naproxen avoided acetaminophen due to lfts  cholesterol reported history of hyperlipidemia however cholesterol panel within normal limits and therefore did not start any medication  nutrition reported 50lbs weight loss over last 6 months nutrition was consulted and recommended encouraging po intake prn electrolyte repletion and consideration of morning carnation instant if insufficient po intake  macrocytosis likely secondary to etoh b12 within normal limits socialmilieupt was encouraged to participate in units groupsmilieutherapy opportunities per occupational therapy staff patient attended the majority of groups and was an active participant patient and  mother were involved in family meeting focused on brief_hospital_course: mr  was evaluated by the medical service in the emergency room and admitted to the hospital for further management of his left pneumothorax his pigtail catheter was on suction and a large air leak was noted but his chest xray showed incomplete expansion of the lung  on  he went to  for a ct guided left pleural pigtail catheter which was attached to 20 cm suction  his air leak persisted and the lung was slightly better expanded  his xarelto was stopped in case any type of surgical intervention was needed the interventional pulmonary sevice was consulted for possible endobronchial valve placement and that was attempted on  but was unsuccessful his air leak gradually decreased over time and decreased amounts of suction were applied to his chest tube he finally underwent a waterseal trial on  but developed significant subcutaneous emphysema involving his left chest neck face including both eyes and his voice was high pitched  the tube was placed back on 40 cm suction to help decrease some of the subcutaneous emphysema which helped but at that point surgery was recommendedon  he was taken to the operating room where he underwent a left thoracoscopy lysis of adhesions resection of blebs pleurodesis and creation of subcutaneous vent he tolerated that procedure well and returned to the sicu intubated and in stable condition he remained intubated overnight but was easily extubated on the morning after surgery  his chest tube was on 20 cm suction and had an air leak  he remained on suction for 48 hours and his chest xray showed almost full expansion of his left lung  he had a left infraclavicular incision in the or to help relieve some of the subcutaneous emphysema and a wound vac was placed on the site the vac helped relieve the crepitus in his face eyes neck and chest over a few days  as his air leak gradually resolved he underwent a successful clamp trial on  and his chest tube then removed his vac was removed on  and the area is loosely packed with a moistened  and dsd until it heals by secondary intention  his chest xray has been stable with a tiny left apical pneumothorax  his oxygen saturations range from 9096his blood sugars have ranged  150 post op but his metformin and glipizide were held until his creatinine recovered peak 18 current 14 he was covered with regular insulin but now that his creatinine is back to baseline both drugs were resumed on urinary retention has been an issue post op and despite being back on his flomax and increasing his activity hes required multiple straight caths and failed 3 voiding trials on  a foley catheter was placed to a leg bag and he will follow up in the  next week for a voiding trial  ua and uc are pending at the time of this summaryafter a longer than expected stay he was discharged to home with  services for his wounds care suture removal and foley catheter  teaching  he was discharged on  and will follow up in the  next week and with dr  in 2 weeks

brief_hospital_course: after ed evaluation patient was admitted for further evaluation  once hospitalized the patient had an ercp which shwed sludge in the common bile duct which was cleared by the procedure  patient also had a ruq us which showed cholelithiasis  patient was assumed to have a passed gallstone and was brought to the operating room for gallbladder removal with dr   operative report is as follows the patient was brought to the operative theater  general anesthesia was induced  the patient was prepared and draped in the usual fashion  a time out was now performed  we entered the abdomen through an infraumbilical smile incision which was anesthetized as allports were with 05 marcaine  the incision was taken down bluntly to the linea   linea  was elevated between  clamps and incised  we now penetrated the peritoneum bluntly with a single pass of a blunt  clamp  we now placed a 12  type port and insufflated the abdomen to 15 mmhg  we now passed a 30 degree angled laparoscopic into the abdomen and explored  the right upper quadrantrevealed the gallbladder was not particularly adherent to the surrounding tissues but was quite whitened as typical of chronic cholecystitis  it also had a layer of rather fragile edematous tissues around it which were moderatelytroublesome during the course of the case  we began the case by placing a 12 mm port in the epigastrium and subsequently two 5 mm ports were placed in the subcostal regions in the mid clavicular and lateral clavicular lines  we now retracted cephalad on the gallbladder on its fundus and pulled the ampulla to the right  using  as well as  dissection we now suppressed the soft tissueoff of the lateral edge of the cystic duct area eventually defining the cystic duct lateral margin  we now slowly suppressed the soft tissue off of the cystic duct and allowed the cystic artery which was lying fairly close over the cystic duct to fall back to the patients left by dividing some of its rightsided ramifications using cautery  this now enabled us to isolate the cystic artery high up and divided between 2 clips proximally and 1 distally  we now cleaned the remainder of the cystic duct and divided it between 2 clips proximally and 1 distally  we now commenced elevating the gallbladder off of the liver bed  because of some dense adhesions in this area a cholecystotomy was made and we spilled some bile but there was not a lot of stone debris seen  all of this was irrigated free with a suctionirrigator and the right upper quadrant cleansed several times before we finished the case  we now completed dissecting the gallbladder off of the liver bed until it wasattached only by the free edge of the liver  at this time we examined the dissection area in great detail and were very satisfied with both hemostasis and the clips on the cystic duct  the attachments of the gallbladder and the free edgeof liver were now lysed and the gallbladder pulled out through the epigastric port  at this time we once more irrigated the abdomen and removed all irrigant and debris we now removed the trocars sequentially and found a pesky bleeder on the epigastric trocar site  this was controlled with cautery from the right flank port site  when this was dry we now once more irrigated and were satisfied with hemostasis throughout  the remainder of the ports were removed  we now closed the umbilical port using the 2 stay sutures of 0 vicryl plus an intervening figureofeight vicryl suture  this resulted in a very satisfactory closure the skin wounds were anesthetized thoroughly with 05 marcaine  the subcutaneous tissues and skin were closed with  monocryl  benzoin and steristrips were applied  2 x 2s and tegaderm were applied  procedure was terminatedshe tolerated the procedure well and was extubated upon completion she we subsequently taken to the pacu for recovery she was transferred to the surgical floor hemodynamically stable her vital signs were routinely monitored and she remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable she was initially given iv fluids postoperatively which were discontinued when she was tolerating pos her diet was advanced on the morning of  to regular which she tolerated without abdominal pain nausea or vomiting she was voiding adequate amounts of urine without difficulty she was encouraged to mobilize out of bed and ambulate as tolerated which she was able to do independently her pain level was routinely assessed and well controlled at discharge with an oral regimen as needed on  she was discharged home with scheduled follow up in  clinic in 2 weeks

by ambulance after a question of intentional overdose on percocet in the setting of alcohol intoxication and an altercation with his girlfriend has had a number of altercations one of them with a domestic violence charge  upon arrival to the  er the patient was combatative and required po haldol and ativan in addition to 9 people to restrain him  overnight on  mr  became acutely aggressive and assaulted his father upon attempting to elope from the  the patient punched his father several times in the face and required chemical and physical restraints 3 point leather restraints for 4 hours l arm left free given injury given 5mg im haldol 2mg im ativan  on  he was calm and cooperative recieved seroquel for anxiety percocet for pain and had a visit with his girlfriend  as of the time of admission mr  had not had any evidence of aggression x 3 days in the emergency room      during his admission mr  consistently reported that he had not overdosed on percocet and had not tried to commit suicide he denied being depressed and through out the admission was future oriented and expressed that he was ashamed of his behavior especially in the emergency room he would endorse that he had been drinking too much and had utilized percocet inappropriately snorting and he had also been using cocaine  he expressed frustration for hospitalization but remained cooperative and appropriate to others and remained in good behavioral control through out he was cooperative with the team in also collecting collateral information and records were obtained from past hospitalizations from  and  when he had presented for mood dysregulation and suicidality as well when talking about his past suicide attempts through aspirin overdose or hanging himself with a belt he notes that this was when he was young and stupid and would not do that again through serial evaluation it appeared that mr  has a long standing vulnerability to anger epsiodes impulsivity amd mood dysregualation and prior to admission this was further worsened by his substance abuse which had been escalating significantly in order to target these symptoms to reduce his risk through time a mood stabilizing medication was strongly reccommended he accepted seroquel with good tolerability and this was started at 50mg q daily and 200mg qhs he stated that he felt this was helpful for his anxiety and sleep and expressed commitment to take it outside of the hospital his vulnerability to mood swings was explained and the hope is this would also be helpful in reducing his anger outbursts through time in addition to medication ongoing therapy and sobriety were emphasized in the hospital he did state that he needed to avoid substances as he could see that they contributed to his situation here and it woudl be important in order to avoid rehospitalization and trouble with the law in the future he was agreeable to referral to intensive outpatinet evening program for addiction he wishes to return to work intense dysfunctional relationships are significnat triggers for the patient in discharge planning a phone conference was held with the treatment team patient and patients mother  patient excused himself from a team phone meeting with his mother but remained calm and collected and illustrated an ability to remove himself from a situation and utilize coping skills when most overwhelemed the mother is supportive of patients treatment plan and patient expressed that he would call his mom when he has difficulty controlling his emotions or needed support or a place to stay she has assisted him in attending his appointments in the past and was provided with a detailed list of follow up appointments at time of discharge the patient remained euthymic in his mood but annoyed with hospitalization he was clearly future oriented and without suicidal ideation plan or intent he stated that he no longer saw the point in suicide as he would not want to hurt his mom and he did not see suicide as something that would end his life but it would be something to hurt another he feels that he would rather be a thorn to somebody than take his life however at this time he did not have any intentions of annoying or harming another at time of discharge the patient no longer presented as an acute risk to himself or others and all modifiable risk factors had been addressed targeting mood stabilization focus on sobriety and sober supports addressing relationship conflicts and increasing supports he certainly remains at a chronic risk of relapse into dangerous behaviors to self and others when overwhelemed and intoxicated as this has been an issue since age  he and his loved ones have a clear understanding of this risk and know how to seek help if neededthere was some concern ercp or steroid use and there was no evidence of gallstones on imaging his  score was calculated to be 7 he received aggressive fluid resuscitation and was started on iv meropenem given his very significant resuscitation requirements the patient was intubated to maintain oxygenation and ventilation in the setting of worsening anasarca and thirdspacing of fluid surgery did not feel that his presentation warranted operative management the patient initially began to show interval improvement after the first 48 hours as measured by lab abnormalities and fluid resuscitaton requirements but and had a passymuir valve placed of note on the afternoon after having the sutures removed from his tracheostomy site the patients trach tube was noted to be out of proper position anesthesia and ct underlying infection eventually he grew coag neg staph sensitive to linezolid in consecutive blood cultures from  and then coag neg staph that was resistant to linezolid in a blood culture on allergic reaction was also thought to be a possible source of his staph he underwent multiple cvl changes given these positive cultures tee negative for vegetations or abscesses also he grew developed this rash he was empirically switched to aztreonamflagyl given concern for a druginduced reaction ie dress syndrome  dermatology was consulted and agreed that the rash likely represented a drug reaction but felt that the likely inciting agent was unasyn approximately two weeks prior to rash development biopsies were performed and were also consistent with a hypersensitivity reaction brief_hospital_course: mr  was admitted to the colorectal surgery service on  after undergoing a planned laparoscopic proctocolectomy and mobilization of splenic flexure and ileal pouch anal anastomosis with diverting loop ileostomy he tolerated the procedure well and was extubated in the or prior to recovering in the pacu for full details please see the dictated operative report postoperatively he was kept npo with iv fluids a dilaudid pca and a foley catheter on pod 1 his diet was advanced to clears midday pod one the patient was noted to be rigorous with a temperature of 996 and hr to 145 he was triggered for these findings he was in sinus rhythm hematocrit was stable and he was otherwise hemodynamically stable he was given a liter of lactated ringers the patient stated that he was feeling overall well and his pain was controlled the jp drain was putting out a moderate amount of serous fluid it was not particularly bloody ciprofloxacin and flagyl were started intravenously he was putting appropriate amounts of urine all surgical incision lines were intact and closed with dermabond over the next four hours the patients heart rate improved to 100120 however his temperature was 1015 and blood cultures were ordered the patient was given cipro and flagyl which was then expanded to vancomycin and zosyn when he became febrile the patient remained tachycardic throughout the evening and into the night however he appeared stable he was monitored closely by the surgical team attending and nursing staff he continued to make appropriate amounts of urine and pass stool and flatus from the ostomy it was thought that a sirs response was most likely responsible for the tachycardia his white blood cell count was noted to be 30 in the morning of postoperative day two the patient was given an intravenous fluid bolus for continued tachycardia with some response a chest xray was obtained which the radiology thought could possibly be a pneumonia the patient had no respiratory symptoms he was on antibiotics there was no free air on the chest film he was monitored closely he appeared to be stable and had minimal complaints his pain was controlled his heart rate decreased to 100115 after the fluid however in the afternoon the patient again was tachycardic primarily when standing he was noted to have a systolic blood pressure down to 73 when standing and 116 in bed he was given iv fluids although the patient had been off of steroids for  weeks prior to surgery a random cortisol level was obtained and found to be normal a steroid taper was started in attempt to improve the heart rate without effect on afternoon rounds of this day dr  a rectal exam at the bedside to evaluate the pouch and to be sure there was no fluid within the pouch and this was normal on pod 3 he was started on clears and eventually a regular diet which he tolerated well his tachycardia had improved however his wbc was stable at 36 his received a transfusion of 1 unit of prbcs for a hct of 22 with an increase to 24 his foley was accidentally removed and he failed to void requiring replacement with the addition of flomax on pod 5 his wbc improved to 12 his foley was removed and he voided without difficulty the following day he was noted to have high ostomy output and he was subsequently started on loperamide 4mg qid as well as psyllium wafers his ostomy output improved thereafter his antibiotics were discontinued on pod7 his surgical drain was removed he complained of dysuria and ua was checked and found to be negative because his ostomy output was much improved his loperamide dose was decreased to 2 mg tid and was reduced to bid the following day because he was tolerating a diet his pain was well controlled he was ambulating without difficulty he was discharged to home on  on a steroid taper with instructions to follow up in the colorectal surgery clinic
past_medical_history: ulcerative colitis
